2.text:
Italian Libya. 5th Light Division has stopped
in it’s tracks during the middle of a major

8.text:
offensive. There’s no fuel, they can only
mount defensive maneuvers. Their commander,

16.text:
Streich, predicts he’ll need four days to
refuel the division. Rommel has none of it.

24.text:
He tells Streich to strip all vehicles he
can spare and send them back for fuel. Thanks

30.text:
to Rommel, instead of four days, the 5th Light
Division is ready to move only 24 hours later.

39.text:
Intro text
It’s the 12th of February 1941. Rommel reaches

48.text:
Tripoli and meets the new commander of the
-shattered- Italian forces, General Gariboldi.

54.text:
The British have just won a stunning victory,
annihilating the Italian 10th Army during

61.text:
Operation Compass, and there’s barely anything
between them and the last Italian port at

66.text:
Tripoli. Both Rommel and Gariboldi agree to
hold Sirte, thinking that the British will

73.text:
come forwards. Rommel throws elements of the
German 5th “Light” motorized division

78.text:
at Sirte, even before the whole unit arrives
- such is the desperation and almost panic

85.text:
on the Axis side. This was Rommel’s one
and only chance to save Italian North Africa.

93.text:
And yet, there’s no contact with the British.
They never come forwards. Wavell, Commander

102.text:
in Chief of the Middle East, is on the brink
of total victory. Yet, what could have been

109.text:
his, is now squarely in Rommel’s hands.
And the opportunity for Wavell to remove Axis

117.text:
forces from North Africa is missed... Because
Churchill wants to go to Greece.

124.text:
For Britain’s Prime Minister, Greece was
more important, and priority of reinforcements

131.text:
and resupply should go to Greece and not to
the Western Desert. Wavell, who is about to

138.text:
be fighting five different campaigns at the
same time, is forced to concede to the Prime

144.text:
Minister’s wishes and has no choice but
to send everything he can spare away from

150.text:
Libya. O’Connor abandons his plan to take
Tripoli. He knows it’s unlikely that the

158.text:
Italians can stop him, but it is never to
be. By the time Rommel arrives, the Western

164.text:
Desert Force is no longer. A new static HQ
is set up - Cyrenaica Command - lead by General

172.text:
Neame. 7th Armoured Division is cast throughout
Egypt for rest and refit duties, and the 6th

180.text:
Australian Division is sent to Greece. Effectively,
in a blink of an eye, Churchill robs O’Connor

188.text:
and Wavell of total victory. And through intelligence
reports, Wavell knows the Germans are coming.

196.text:
It’s the 1st of March. Rommel is an unknown.
His forces are weak. And the might of the

205.text:
British Empire stands before him. His goal
is to prevent that Empire from crushing him.

213.text:
And taking what’s left of Italian Libya.
He concludes that there aren’t many British

218.text:
units at the front and so decides to defend
- not from Sirte - but from El Agheila, which

226.text:
is currently held by the British. The marshes
running south from the coast about 20 miles

232.text:
west of El Agheila would provide better protection
on the defense than Sirte. Rommel sends his

239.text:
forces forwards, and the Germans occupy the
Oasis of Marada on the 13th March whilst the

246.text:
Italian Armoured Ariete Division moves East
of Nofilia. Commanded by Major General Streich,

254.text:
the German 5th Light Division is actually
a new unit… formed from a cadre of troops

260.text:
from the 3rd Panzer Division, veterans of
the French campaign. Despite being a “Light”

267.text:
division, it boasts 70 light and 80 medium
tanks. It’s not really “light”.

274.text:
And it’s certainly better than what the
British have. Wavell has little choice but

280.text:
to leave Cyrenaica in the hands of Cyrenaica
Command and General Neame. In his youth, General

288.text:
Neame won and is still to this day, the only
person to ever win both a Victoria Cross and

296.text:
an Olympic Gold Medal. But Neame is pessimistic
about the entire situation. His HQ has a severe

305.text:
lack of trained staff and is incapable of
controlling mobile operations. Neame has the

312.text:
difficult task of defending the whole of Cyrenaica
with only one incomplete armoured formation.

319.text:
2nd Armoured Division is commanded by General
Gambier-Parry, except the Division isn’t

327.text:
really a division. It only has one armoured
brigade, the 3rd (commanded by Brigadier Remington),

333.text:
and that only has two out of its three regiments
in the area - the 5th Royal Tank Regiment,

339.text:
armed with British light tanks, and the 6th
Royal Tank Regiment, armed with captured Italian

345.text:
M11/39 tanks. Captured Italian tanks, whose
performance was awful during Operation Compass.

355.text:
2nd Armoured Division’s Support Group lead
by Brigadier Latham is equally as poor. Split

362.text:
up and nowhere near full-strength, it consists
of only one motor battalion, one 25 pounder

368.text:
regiment, an anti-tank battery and one machine
gun company. So basically 2nd Armoured Division

375.text:
isn’t an armoured formation and lacks equipment
to make it even an effective fighting force.

382.text:
Wavell isn’t happy with Neame’s pessimistic
attitude, the terrain, or the strength of

389.text:
the enemy reinforcements. He instructs Neame
to fall back if attacked and try to preserve

397.text:
his forces. Wavell gambles everything on the
idea that the Germans won’t be able to attack

404.text:
in strength before May. If he can delay long
enough, he might be able to reinforce Cyrenaica.

414.text:
Rommel suggests to Gariboldi that an all-out
offensive against the British is a possibility.

421.text:
He states his aims as reoccupying Cyrenaica
and pushing on into Northwest Egypt. All with

428.text:
the ultimate aim of taking the Suez canal.
He sends plans for this offensive to the German

437.text:
High Command. But the OKH see his plans as
far too ambitious. Chief of the General Staff,

445.text:
Franz Halder, dislikes Rommel, and urges caution
and a defensive posture, which Rommel ultimately

452.text:
accepts, much to the relief of Gariboldi.
Gariboldi knows the Italians aren’t prepared

459.text:
for war. A major offensive is out of the question,
especially since the last one went so badly.

467.text:
But it wouldn’t be down to him. On the 18th
of March, Rommel guesses that the British

472.text:
have no offensive capability and are perhaps
even thinning out the front. He flies to Berlin,

478.text:
and the OKH once again tell him to go slow.
They suggest that the supply situation is

486.text:
too weak to mount a major attack, but would
allow a limited offensive to take the Agedabia

494.text:
area. Once that battle is over, they would
decide if Rommel was to move from there, onwards.

502.text:
Rommel is also told that there are no more
units to come after the 15th Panzer Division

507.text:
is offloaded, except replacements for losses
sustained in the campaign. Without reinforcements

513.text:
and without the real support of his superiors,
or his allies, Rommel is effectively on his own.

521.text:
Frustrated, he’s back at his HQ on the 23rd
of March, to witness the British withdrawing

528.text:
from El Agheila. In the previous days, General
Streich of 5th Light Division planned a reconnaissance

535.text:
raid in force against the British-held Mersa
Brega area. And when Rommel learns of the

542.text:
plans he sanctions the raid, and also states
that El Agheila is to be captured too. Getting

550.text:
past the town would open the door to the Cyrenaica
desert beyond and Rommel sees his chance.

557.text:
The 3rd Reconnaissance Battalion, with their
8 wheeled armoured cars fitted with 20mm cannon,

564.text:
drive the British patrols from El Agheila,
whose own armoured cars simply can’t hope

569.text:
to match the Germans. 30th of March, Streich
is ordered to take Mersa Brega the following

576.text:
day. Rommel knows that if the British have
time to dig in at Mersa Brega it would present

582.text:
a formidable obstacle to any future advance.
He knows he must take it now. Gariboldi reluctantly

592.text:
approves Rommel’s plan, but forbids any
advance beyond Mersa Brega, unless he gives

599.text:
consent. So Rommel orders his units forwards
towards Mersa Brega.

605.text:
The battle begins. 31st of March, 10am. Mersa
Brega. The cautious advance of 3rd Recon is

614.text:
met by the British, and successfully resisted
in the morning. But concerned that a prolonged

620.text:
battle would wear out his men, Latham, commander
of 2nd Armour’s Support Group asks for Remington’s

627.text:
3rd Armoured Brigade to attack the German
right flank. It’s the afternoon, and Gambier-Parry

634.text:
doesn’t think there’s enough time to get
his forces onto the offensive this day. And

641.text:
so Remington’s Brigade doesn’t move. 5pm.
Under Rommel’s direct leadership, the Germans

649.text:
dive-bomb and then assault the British right
flank. Latham and the Support Group hold their

654.text:
positions all day, but it looks like they’ll
be surrounded if they stay here. With no choice,

660.text:
Latham orders a retreat and they fall back
to a position southwest of Agedabia. The bottleneck

667.text:
at El Agheila and Mersa Brega is taken and
the British right flank is now open for Rommel

677.text:
1st of April. “Attack, momentum, force”. Rommel faces
a dilemma. The door to Cyrenaica is open,

687.text:
but his orders forbid him from any further
advance. Rommel turns to Streich, and asks

695.text:
“When are we going to meet in Agedabia?”.
Streich says “I don’t know - we’ll have

702.text:
to see about that”. British air reconnaissance
spots a large force of vehicles near El Agheila.

709.text:
The Germans advance in two columns. 3rd Reconnaissance
Battalion, accompanied by 8th Motorized Machine

716.text:
Gun Battalion and 5th Panzer Regiment, advance
down the main coastal road. They have artillery

722.text:
and anti-tank support. The 2nd Motorized Machine
Gun Battalion and a Panzerjager unit attempt

729.text:
to encircle the British from the south. Unfortunately,
the second column is slowed and then halted

735.text:
by the terrain. Behind them all, the Ariete
and Bresca Division sit ready to move at a

744.text:
The 2nd of April, 7am. 5th Light Division
is moving towards Agedabia. 2nd Support Group

752.text:
is attacked. Neame orders Latham to block
the road to Benghazi should the Germans commit

759.text:
to the attack. Neame also orders General Gambier-Parry
to move 3rd Armoured Brigade to Sceleidima

765.text:
with the intention to strike west or south-east
on the flank of an enemy advance, depending

772.text:
on which way the Germans move. Wanting to
preserve his forces, Neame tells Gambier-Parry

777.text:
not to commit 3rd Armoured Brigade unless
he has Neame’s expressed permission. Having

784.text:
heard of the attack, General Wavell arrives
at Barce to see what’s going on at the front.

789.text:
He’s not happy with the situation, or with
Neame’s performance.

794.text:
In the afternoon the unsupported Support Group
is battered by the Germans. Rommel catches

802.text:
up to Streich. “What’s going on here?”
he asks. “I thought we ought not to give

807.text:
the enemy a chance to dig in all over again,”
Streich said, “so I’m moving my whole

813.text:
division forward, and I’m about to attack
Agedabia.” “Those were not my instructions,

819.text:
but I approve.” Rommel is sliding over into
the realm of insubordination. And Gariboldi

828.text:
is furious. “This is in contradiction to
what I ordered! You are to wait for me before

835.text:
continuing any advance!” If things go wrong,
Italian forces will be caught out in the open

841.text:
and will probably be destroyed. The majority
of the Italian units are unmotorized, so if

847.text:
the Germans retreat, the Italians will be
left to the mercy of a British counterattack.

854.text:
But Rommel ignores Gariboldi’s protests
and presses on with his attacks. It’s a

859.text:
gamble that, if it was to fail, could result
in serious consequences for his military career.

866.text:
But he cannot allow the British to dig in
and regain their strength. He must defeat

873.text:
Gambier-Parry acknowledges Neame’s new order
not to commit the 3rd Armoured Brigade to

879.text:
battle prematurely. but he requests permission
to make the decision to commit when he thinks

885.text:
it’s best, since he’s closer to the action
and has a better understanding of what’s

890.text:
going on. He understands the situation is
turning against the British and needs to withdraw

896.text:
from Agedabia. But he disagrees with Neame’s
idea to send the Support Group down the coast

902.text:
road and split it from the rest of 2nd Armoured.
Neame wants the coast road covered, especially

909.text:
because the inexperienced Australian 9th Division
would be exposed if it isn’t covered. But

916.text:
Gambier-Parry fears that if his division splits
in two, both parts will be weak and isolated,

921.text:
and he wants to avoid a defeat in detail.
This eventuality has a real chance of coming

927.text:
true, since only 22 cruisers and 25 light
tanks remain in 3rd Armoured Brigade, and

933.text:
they’re in poor repair as it is. Gambier-Parry
knows he cannot split his force as that would

942.text:
Neame is about to agree with Gambier-Parry
when Wavell intervenes. He has no confidence

949.text:
in Neame’s ability to parry Rommel’s attack.
Wavell orders Benghazi to be covered. He insists

957.text:
that the 2nd Armoured Division is to operate
together up until El Magrun, at which point

963.text:
the Support Group is to go up the coast and
the rest of the Division is to withdraw through

967.text:
Sceleidima to El Abiar and cover the flank
of the 9th Australian Division. Wavell is

973.text:
trying to block the road to Benghazi, thinking
that this is Rommel’s ultimate goal. But

979.text:
his order to cover the 9th’s retreat directly
contradicts his previous orders to conserve

986.text:
the armoured forces and to intentionally give
up ground to the enemy. It places 2nd Armoured

992.text:
Division on the coast, opening up it’s right
flank for Rommel. Wavell guesses (based on

999.text:
recent intelligence reports) that the Germans
aren’t ready for a major operation and must

1005.text:
be going for a quick objective like Benghazi.
It’s his only hope. He knows that the German

1011.text:
High Command hasn’t sanctioned a major attack
and Rommel is most likely just probing forwards.

1018.text:
And besides, he has to protect the 9th Australian
Division.

1022.text:
The withdraw of the 2nd Armoured Division
begins. With Latham’s group no longer able

1027.text:
to hold, 5th Royal Tank Regiment covers the
rear, which is harassed by 2nd Battalion of

1034.text:
the 5th Panzer Regiment. In one engagement,
5th Royal Tank Regiment loses five tanks and

1039.text:
the Germans three, which is enough to force
the British to continue their withdraw. The

1045.text:
problem is that the further the British retreat,
the more tanks they lose. They’re suffering

1050.text:
from a strained logistics chain that stretches
back all the way to Alexandria.

1056.text:
Getting spare parts to the front is proving
a nightmare. The tanks are at the end of their

1062.text:
life-spans, and are so badly in need of repair
they’re suffering one breakdown every ten

1068.text:
miles. And on the retreat, they can’t repair
them, and so have to abandon them.

1073.text:
Brigadier Harding, who is Neame’s staff
officer, confirms Wavell’s fears about Neame’s

1080.text:
performance. Not only does Neame not fully
understand where his units are or seek that

1086.text:
information out, but Harding also begs Wavell
to bring O’Connor back. Wavell takes command

1093.text:
of operations and sends a message to Cairo.
O’Connor, Wavell’s desert ace, sets off

1102.text:
And as the front collapses, General O’Connor
arrives on the 3rd of April with Brigadier

1108.text:
Combe. Both are experienced desert commanders
who’d beaten the Italians during Operation

1114.text:
Compass, O’Connor being Wavell’s ace up
his sleeve. Wavell is concerned. He has so

1121.text:
little confidence in Neame by this point that
he desires to make O’Connor commander of

1127.text:
Cyrenaica Command. Placing O’Connor in command
would pit a proven and veteran commander against

1133.text:
Rommel and shift the odds in the British favour.
But O’Connor points out that a change of

1139.text:
leadership at this point could cause more
confusion than it’s worth. O’Connor does

1143.text:
not know the units and is reluctant to take
control in the middle of a battle that was

1148.text:
progressing so badly. O’Connor shares Neame’s
view that Rommel will go straight across the

1154.text:
desert - just like O’Connor had done earlier
in the year. Doing so will cut off British

1159.text:
forces in North Cyrenaica and result in a
decisive victory. O’Connor proposes that

1165.text:
Wavell should leave Neame in command and O’Connor
would become Neame’s “advisor” for now.

1174.text:
Wavell agrees. So effectively, Cyrenaica Command
now has two commanders, with a third breathing

1185.text:
Rommel needs every tactical advantage he can
get if he is to slay the Cerberus, and so

1190.text:
decides to lead from the front. He robs fuel
from the rest of 5th Light Division and takes

1195.text:
charge of 3rd Reconnaissance Battalion, driving
up towards Soluch. Rommel’s advance prompts

1203.text:
the start of the demolition plan in Benghazi
to get rid of the captured Italian ammo. But

1209.text:
there is that much of it that it looks like
the British won’t have time to destroy it

1214.text:
all. Rommel orders other units to press on
in whatever manner they can. Lieutenant Colonel

1219.text:
Graf Schwerin (commander of 200th Schutzen
Brigade) forms a Kampfgruppe (a battle-group)

1226.text:
from various units, including an infantry
unit which is detached from the Italian Ariete

1231.text:
Division. This Kampfgruppe recons towards
Msus.

1236.text:
In the afternoon of the 3rd, 2nd Armoured
reaches Sceleidima with 6th Royal Tank Regiment

1242.text:
forming a rearguard with its Italian tanks.
But this opens the British flank, with nothing

1248.text:
to stop the Germans moving through Antelat
to Msus. Knowing this, Gambier-Parry orders

1255.text:
a regrouping of units, and confusion reigns
in 3rd Armoured Brigade as a string of contradictory

1261.text:
orders are received from both Gambier-Perry
and Cyrenaica headquarters.

1266.text: At the worst possible time, 3rd Armoured Brigade’s

1270.text:
wireless sets decide to fail after the unit
begins a move towards Msus, only for Remington

1277.text:
to hear a new order to go to El Abiar. Unable
to communicate with his superiors to verify

1283.text:
the change of orders, Remington decides to
continue to Msus, only to find that the French

1289.text:
Motor Battalion there has destroyed all the
petrol and a portion of the other stores before

1296.text:
withdrawing. So most of 2nd Armoured Division
is now at El Abiar, whilst 3rd Armoured Brigade

1303.text: is at Msus, thirsty for fuel.

1306.text:
But the fuel situation for the Germans is
worse. The bulk of 5th Light Division is now

1312.text:
stopped completely between Agedabia and Zuetina.
There’s so little fuel left, they can only

1319.text:
mount defensive maneuvers. Rommel hadn’t
informed his quartermaster about his attack,

1326.text:
and there had been no time to arrange the
supplies and convoys needed to carry fuel

1331.text:
to the Panzers. Worse, Streich looks at the
situation and predicts he will need four days

1338.text:
at the current logistical rate to refuel his
division. Rommel isn’t having any of it.

1344.text:
He loses his patience with Streich, orders
the division to strip all vehicles it can

1349.text:
spare and sends them back all the way past
El Agheila for fuel, which they then take

1355.text:
back to the division. The 5th Light Division
is ready to move by the evening of the 4th

1360.text:
of April, 24 hours later. This decisive move
allows Rommel’s offensive to continue.

1366.text:
3rd of April, evening. Gariboldi catches up
to Rommel and forbids him from advancing any

1373.text:
further. He warns Rommel to check with Comando
Supremo (Mussolini) before advancing as he

1380.text:
is directly disobeying his orders. Rommel
says that it would be too slow a process to

1386.text:
contact Comando Supremo and insists that he
will have freedom to do what he must. As they

1392.text:
argue, a letter comes from the German high
command ordering Rommel not to advance any

1397.text:
further. But Rommel calls Gariboldi’s bluff,
and tells Gariboldi that the letter gives

1404.text:
him permission from his superiors to act as
he wants. Gariboldi, who can’t read German,

1412.text:
argues that he is Rommel’s superior and
that Rommel has to listen to him. As he is

1418.text:
doing this a second letter arrives announcing
that Benghazi has fallen. Gariboldi leaves

1425.text:
without saying a word. Rommel has directly
disobeyed orders to complete an objective

1432.text:
he was ordered to take perhaps a month or
two down the road. And he gets away with it.

1437.text:
He has a bigger problem though - the British
Empire! Orders or not, Rommel will advance.

1444.text:
And so Benghazi falls to the 3rd Reconnaissance
Battalion that evening as the clock slips

1449.text:
over to the 4th of April. When Rommel arrives
in the town, he comes across a blackboard

1455.text:
where a British soldier has written “Please
keep tidy! Back soon!” Rommel grins and

1461.text:
says “We’ll see about that!” He orders
3rd Reconnaissance Battalion to move towards

1466.text:
Mechili as soon as the Brescia division arrives.
Then orders his forces to split into several

1473.text:
Kampfgruppen - or battlegroups - are ad hoc
formations of various units grouped together,

1481.text:
given a leader and a task. The Germans use
kampfgruppen successfully throughout the war

1487.text:
as their doctrines make it easy for units
to reorganise under new commanders with little

1492.text:
confusion. Usually these kampfgruppen are
given names, but in this case they aren’t.

1499.text:
So since no one else has named them, we will
name them now.

1502.text:
Kampfgruppe Streicht (5th Light Division’s
commander) is made up from the entirety of

1508.text:
Ponath’s 8th Motorized Machine Gun Battalion,
as well as a squadron from 5th Panzer Regiment

1514.text:
and one anti-tank Panzerjager company. This
Kampfgruppe races off towards Tobruk. Kampfgruppe

1520.text:
Olbrich is made up of Olbrich’s 5th Panzer
Regiment with 2nd Motorized Machine Gun Battalion,

1526.text:
as well as tanks from the Ariete Division.
This kampfgruppe sets off towards Msus, with

1532.text:
the eventual goal of Mechili. Kampfgruppe
Schwerin with the rest of his 200th Schutzen

1537.text:
Regiment, with other German units and an Italian
recon unit from the Ariete Division, is sent

1546.text:
The Fabius unit (which was actually named by
the Italians) - is formed from a motor cyclist

1551.text:
unit supported by guns from Ariete Division
- and is sent towards Mechili, followed by

1556.text:
the rest of the Ariete. Rommel flies between
all the different units, urging them to go

1562.text:
forwards as fast as they can. Such is the
severity of Rommel’s drive that Major General

1568.text:
Kirchheim, who is only visiting North Africa,
is pressed into service and ordered to push

1573.text:
the Brescia Division through the Jebel area,
which he does. Gariboldi is outraged! Splitting

1580.text:
your forces up when your enemy isn’t defeated
in battle flies against every rule in the

1587.text:
Whilst the German side is getting complicated,
on the British side things are slipping beyond

1592.text:
the control of their commanders. Neame wants
to withdraw to Derna and Mechili. O’Connor

1598.text:
agrees and issues orders for this to happen,
as Cyrenaica HQ moves from Barce to Maraua,

1604.text:
near Slonta. 9th Australian Division is ordered
to move from Torca to East of Barce and 2nd

1611.text:
Armoured is ordered to move to Charruba to
cover the Australian flank. The German’s

1617.text:
3rd Reconnaissance Battalion hits the 2/13th
Australian Battalion holding a wide front

1622.text:
at Er Regima. The Germans are checked and
withdraw. However, the Australians are ordered

1629.text:
to retreat after their victory. Why? Because
the “rot” has set in. British units now

1635.text:
found themselves retreating faster than the
Germans could catch them. Vehicles that broke

1641.text:
down are abandoned as men hitch rides on other
vehicles rather than spend even a few minutes

1646.text:
trying to fix minor problems. Units are soon
scrambling down the same roads, adding to

1651.text:
the confusion, and battlefield formations
lose their coherency as the hours moved on.

1657.text:
The effectiveness of Cyrenaica Command is
being eaten away by its own flight.

1662.text:
4th of April, the afternoon. 3rd Armoured
Brigade, due to poor fuel and vehicle maintenance,

1670.text:
has arrived at Charruba with only two tanks
left. The rest are abandoned and destroyed

1677.text:
after sifering their fuel for the better tanks.
3rd Armoured Brigade is no longer a fighting

1683.text:
formation even though it hadn’t actually
done much fighting. Remington’s brigade

1689.text:
abandoned most of its tanks because of breakdowns,
a lack of fuel or simply in their haste to

1698.text:
But Rommel isn’t having it all his own way.
In the evening, Schwerin’s group has completely

1704.text:
run out of fuel and is stranded at Ben Gania
